trs: His fiancée, she was his fiancée.
Ah, she was his daughter, his mother's brother's daughter.

src: on-ta leha i-heke tsuẽ ekugu on-ta i-heke
trs: She was repudiating him, she was truely repudiating him a lot.
Nothing, in vain he used to go after her; he used to go after her, and nothing.
Because of that, he untied the ropes of his hammock.
He left her, he left his own wife.

src: üle ineke hale ege-i t-ingunkgingu ineke Kakakugu heke s-ijati-tse-lü eke heke be-ha
trs: ... because that made him sad, because his thoughts made him sad, \textit{Kakakugu} made him an offer, a big snake did so.
“Poor me, poor me, pitiful me," he [\textit{Kamagisa}] said.
“Is it true that she rejected me?" he said.
Because of that he came to him.
Her father is the one who came to him.

src: ingila-be lahale ingila itseke hisuü̃-gü gele uk-enü-bata ege-i
trs: This was a long time ago, when we were still kin to the spirits.
He was sending him to his daughter.
He had already become just like a person.
The snake had already become a person.

src: hm e-ingadzu inha e-te-te nügü i-heke
trs: Hm, “Go to your sister," he said.
“Let's go to your sister," he said.
It seems that his house is a small \textit{cerrado} palm called \textit{ngukuagi}, that stands on a small mound like this.
My deceased father used to say:

src: ah t-indi-sü t-upo-nga leha ija-te-lü leha i-heke
trs: Ah, he then tied his hammock just over his daughter's.

She had a great \textit{genipapo} painting - wow! - she was painted with \textit{genipapo}.’\footnote{\textit{Genipapo} is the fruit of the \textit{Genipa americana} tree. The Kalapalo extract from it a clear liquid used for skin painting, as well as for decorating ceramics and wooden benches. After the liquid oxidizes, it turns black, and may stay on the skin for several days. The liquid may be mixed with charcoal soot to make the painting even darker.}
... ah, she was already his wife.

src: ingati beja i-nha-lü iku-nga-lü leha i-heke leha
trs: He always lay with her in his hammock, and he always had sex with her.
He always really had sex with her.
Ah, who knows how he did it ...
He was teaching him ... with songs of mortuary effigies.
With songs of mortuary effigies... ah, he was teaching him.
Ah, he was teaching his daughter's husband.
He went to visit his mother for a while.

src: tü-ti inha hõhõ s-i-nügü Kamagisa e-nügü
trs: \textit{Kamagisa} came to visit his mother for a while.
She was walking right behind her husband, like his shadow.
When the sun was here, they arrived.
His wife could not be seen by her sisters-in-law.
But she was there, she was going with him.

src: a-hameti-gü-ko ako-ngo akets=uge-i nügü i-heke t-ingajomo heke
trs: “I'm in the company of your sister-in-law," he said to his sisters.
“I'm in the company of your sister-in-law."
“You may greet your sister-in-law," he said.
“Are you really here?" they may have said.
“\textit{Shhh}" - she answered in the snake's language.
Ah, and then she revealed her body.
When they lay down together, her hair was hanging downwards.

src: ande leha i-hameti-jaõ heke ingi-nga-lü leha
trs: Now her sisters-in-law could already see her.
Then, they came back to their village.
There, his father-in-law was teaching him.
About the songs of mortuary effigies.
About the songs of mortuary effigies.
Done, it was finished for him.

src: etsu-ke hetsange hõhõ i-haki-tomi e-heke nügü i-heke
trs: “You may sing for the first time, to reveal your songs," he said.

src: etsu-ke hetsange hõhõ ah i-haki-tomi e-heke nügü i-heke
trs: “You may now sing for the first time, ah, to reveal them," he said.

src: atütü-i beja i-tsa-lü leha i-heke leha
trs: He had already listened to it really well.
He listened to it really well.
Then he arrived in his village.
First he taught the one who was going to be his singing companion.

src: ah t-iko-ngo-ingo aki-ha-lü engü beja otohongo-ingo beja igi-nhun-dote
trs: Ah, he taught the one who was going to be his companion, his other, when he was to sing.
That one who would be his companion.

src: osi-ha ai hale tü-ti heke nügü i-heke
trs: “Let's go," and then he said to his mother:
“Make our image," ah, that's what he said.

src: isi heke tsüle togokige ihe-nügü togoki-be bahale
trs: Then his mother spun cotton, a lot of cotton.
A roll was this big, and another one also had the same size.
This is what would become the effigy's belt.

src: ege hungu jetsa in-ke tsapa akago heke t-üi-ta
trs: Like those, look those they are making.’\footnote{\textit{Ageu} refers to the cotton belts some young men were making at a neighboring house.}
It was meant to be like those.
It was meant to be like those.
The cotton his mother was spinning.
They cut down a log for an effigy.
They had already cut down a log for an effigy.
There was only one, one effigy.

src: üle-pe-a h-ige-i ah tita-be ige t-üi-nga-lü h-ege-i
trs: It's since this that we have been making effigies.
Ah, he sang behind the effigy.

src: angi taka kanga-ki e-te-lü-ko inhalü hungu-be
trs: Did they go fishing? It doesn't seem so ...
Yes, they must have gone fishing.
He was just singing for the first time.
Hm, he was singing for the first time.

src: nhaga-ti bele ekü te-lü tita te-lü leha egea
trs: The effigy was put standing straight in a hole.
This is what they were siging about behind it.
When dusk came, they were singing again.

... Ah, his fire was buried.’\footnote{During the last night of a mortuary ritual, a fire is kept in front of the deceased's effigy. While it is kept burnig, the soul of the deceased is present among the living. At dawn, the fire is buried while a chief makes a speech exhorting the deceased to leave permanently to the village of the dead.}

src: engü beja-ha s-ito-gu-pe-ha ongi-nügü leha mitote
trs: Yes, his fire was buried at dawn.

src: apungu leha ege-i inhalü hale ikindu-ko
trs: That was the end, they didn't wrestle \textit{ikindene}.’\footnote{\textit{Ikindene} is a combat sport practiced by all the peoples of the Upper Xingu, and it is considered one of the most important features of their regional society. Wrestling is the \textit{climax} of the Quarup mortuary ritual, but, since \textit{Kamagisa} didn't have any guests, his ritual also didn't have \textit{ikindene}.}

src: inhalü hale ikindu-ko egea gele h-ege-i gele
trs: They didn't wrestle \textit{ikindene}, it was just like that.

src: ama jeuga ipu-gu i-nkgete u-mbüngai-tsü tühügü h-egei i-heke
trs: “Mother, bring my macaw feathers armlets," that's what he said.

src: üle-tse ingugi-ha isi heke i-ndzüngai-tsü ingi-nügü
trs: It was soon solved, and his mother brought his armlets.

“Mother, bring my oropendola [\textit{Psarocolius sp.}] feathers headdress."’\footnote{The oropendolas — \textit{xexéu}, in Portuguese, and \textit{kui}, in Kalapalo — are birds of the \textit{Psarocolius} genus, whose tail feathers are highly esteemed for their vivid yellow tones.}

src: leku heke ẽ ẽ hügeku heke
trs: He was talking about a headdress called \textit{leku}, yes, yes, about a headdress also called \textit{hügeku}.
That is in the Kamayurá language.
He was saying that in Kamayurá.

src: Kamajula heke küngüa iga-nügü jahu nügü i-heke
trs: The Kamayurá call the oropendola “\textit{jahu}," that's what they say.

src: u-en-tomi-la aketsange u-te-ta leha ige-i leha
trs: “This is so that I'm never coming back, I am leaving."
Before that he sang for the first time.
That was his first time singing.
“You shall not want me to come back."

src: ah a-hati heke seku ũãke u-ti-hu-nhe-ta-tühügü ũãke
trs: “Ah, your niece made my throat swell with sadness in the past."

src: ah nügü leha i-heke tü-ti heke
trs: Ah, he said so to his mother.

src: üi üi üi isi honu-nda leha
trs: “\textit{Üi, üi, üi}" - his mother was crying.

src: kogetsi kogetsi leha ege-i s-i-nügü etsu-tühügü-ngine
trs: On the next day, the day after he came, after he had sung for the first time.
He sang for the first time.
After he had sung for the first time, he came.

src: apungu ekugu leha inhalü leha t-oto-mo-na t-ünga t-etu-na e-te-lü-i leha
trs: He went away for good, he didn't ever come back to his kin, to his house, to his village.

Say “\textit{uitsajingugu}."’\footnote{We could never find a proper translation of this word. A nahukua man once said it would mean `my little shin!', and explained that one should say so to avoid getting lazy after listening to a narrative.}
